title: 113_hr2055
content: The Act titled "Integrated Electronic Health Records (iEHR) for Military and Veterans Act" establishes a prize program for developing a fully-integrated electronic health records program for the Department of Defense and the Department of Veterans Affairs. The Act establishes a $50,000,000 cash prize program for developing an electronic health records program for the Department of Defense and the Department of Veterans Affairs, encouraging broad participation. The Secretaries will announce prize competitions in the Federal Register, detailing the competition's subject, duration, eligibility requirements, registration process, prize amount, and award criteria. The Secretary cannot issue a notice until all prize funds are appropriated. To be eligible to win a prize, an individual or entity must meet certain criteria. To be eligible for a prize under this section, an individual or entity must comply with requirements in the Federal Register notice, be incorporated in the US with a primary place of business, be a US citizen or lawful permanent resident, and not be a Federal entity or employee. A joint panel will be established by the Secretaries of Defense and Veterans Affairs. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will establish a joint panel to develop criteria for an integrated electronic health records program eligible for an award. The panel will include physicians from military departments and the Department of Veterans Affairs. The joint panel, including representatives from the Veterans Benefits Administration, must be appointed within 14 days of the enactment of the Act. They are tasked with establishing specific criteria for developing electronic health records, considering best practices from both private and public sectors. Failure to agree on criteria or insufficient appointments may result in delays. The National Health Information Technology Coordinator will determine criteria for the competition if the panel is not appointed on time. The deadline for submissions is one year after criteria are established. Prizes will be awarded based on the published criteria. The entity awarded a prize under this section will receive a contract with the Department of Defense and the Department of Veterans Affairs to provide an electronic health records program and support for five years, compensated at $25,000,000 per year. Upon contract expiration, intellectual property rights will revert to the Federal Government. The entity awarded a prize under this section will retain intellectual property rights in upgrades to the program developed. The Federal Government will not have rights to intellectual property derived from participation in the competition, except for negotiating a license. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs may require participants in a competition to waive claims against the Federal Government for any injury, death, or property damage. Participants must also obtain liability insurance or show financial responsibility for third-party claims. Participants in a competition may need to waive claims against the Federal Government for injury, death, or property damage. They must also have liability insurance to cover third-party claims, with the Federal Government named as an additional insured for certain damages. The programs created under this section shall not be considered a substitute for Federal research and development programs. $50,000,000 is authorized for this section.
